atues of

arly
example of the grape motif on the base of the Yakushi nyorai statue, s=
o we
are talking middle 500s or so. Squirrels may be included in the motif,=
 but I
can=92t recall right off hand. Thus, there is a definite Buddhist co=
nnection.
The motif shows up in sword fittings rather early and I believe t=
here are
pieces by Joshin or at least around that time with the motif. Ko-K=
inko

ry

 it

the handle went from the male-female posts
or iny=F4kon that passed through=
 the handle and the nakago fastening the
menuki to each other to chikara-ga=
ne. These iny=F4kon posts continued until
the late Muromachi period into th=
e Momoyama period. They are also seen on
generally high class works for the=
 mid to late Edo period; however, they no
longer went all the way through t=
he tsuka and basically worked as the newer
chikara-gane do. As noted, stren=
gth and metal is the literal translation,
but more accurately I would call =
them reinforced/strengthened tabs of
typically copper. On an added note, at=
 least the first three generations of
the main line Goto masters are said t=
o have only used iny=F4kon posts and
